explosion of data generated, both through the anal- ysis of archived clinical material and through prospective stud- ies that expressly collect samples for molecular analyses ( 13)., Fortunately much of this has been made publicly availablethrough shared repositories, enabling investigators without di-rect access to clinical material the opportunity to carry out dis- covery and validation studies to better characterize the molecular basis of tumor behavior and response to therapies(4, 5)., The recent efforts of The Cancer Genome Atlas and other groups to generate comprehensive molecular profiles of humancancers have further enriched these data sets, now using the current state-of-the-art RNA-seq technologies ( 2, 3)., There are few areas of cancer research where gene expres- sion profiling has had as great an impact as in breast cancer.Both in basic research and clinical application, gene expressionanalysis underlies the common molecular classification schemes (eg, intrinsic subtypes), and its importance is second only to the gold standard pathological measurement of estrogenreceptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and human epidermalgrowth factor receptor 2 (HER2) in defining treatment plans for individual patients ( 611)., The development and validation of prognostic gene expression classifiers in early breast cancer (eg OncotypeDX [ 12],  Prosigna [ 13],  Mammaprint [ 14],  Gene expres- sion Grade Index [ 15], and others) has substantially refined ad- juvant chemotherapy decision-making, permitting optimized delivery of this treatment and sparing thousands of women toxic therapy where it is not required ( 16)., Given the central role gene expression analyses play in the in- vestigation and management of breast cancer, the report by Gao etal., (17) describing artifactual gene expression changes in serially sampled specimens collected as part of a randomized controlled trial, are particularly relevant to the design and interpretation ofgene expression biomarker studies., In their accompanying article the authors build on previous reports describing alterations in gene expression related to delays in tissue processing following sam-pling, including substantial changes in early response genes be- tween diagnostic core biopsies and surgical specimens ( 1820)., They now analyze and compare whole-genome expression datafrom samples of ER breast cancers obtained by core needle biopsy at baseline and paired surgical specimens obtained after two weeksof preoperative aromatase inhibitor treatment (AI), or control from the POETIC trial ( 21)., The analysis of gene expression alterations in the treated group identified major signaling pathways known to beaffected by estrogen deprivation, in addition,  as previouslyreported, substantial changes in some genes are documented incontrol-treated patients, which are attributed to pre-analytical vari- ables in sample collection and handling., Namely the baseline core biopsies were processed directly, whereas the surgical specimenswere handled routinely following resection (often with a delay forclinical assessment), and core cut samples were obtained from thepathology specimens., This would result in substantial differences in ischemic time that could produce cellular responses and affect sample integrity., Gao et al. showed that many of the genes whoseexpression is most altered between baseline and surgery in the AI-treated group are also those affected in the control arm (Figure 1) (17)., This is a striking finding as it indicates that the genes that could have been attributed to AI treatment were actually due to aconfounding factor., The possibility that the expression changes inthe surgical samples of the control group were the result of the in-tervening biopsy causing a wound healing, immune,  or other per- turbation was addressed by an analysis of a different trial (FAIMoS), where the post-AI samples were collected by a repeatcore biopsy prior to surgical resection of the tumor ( 22)., With the benefit of treatment and control groups in POETIC the authorsconclude that the sampling differences in serial specimen collec- tion resulted in the detection of purely artifactual changes in some genes, while also masking real treatment-induced changes in othergenes., Received: April 4, 2018; Accepted: April 12, 2018 The Author(s) 2018. Prospective studies toevaluate pharmacodynamic effects of novel therapies are of- ten undertaken in early phase clinical trials, which do not al- ways include a control arm ( 32)., In this setting where analysis of paired samples may be used to adjudicate drug effect, de-termine dosing,  infer potential predictive biomarkers, or iden-tify putative combination partners, care must be taken to account for technical confounders in downstream analyses if technical controls cannot be integrated in the study design.This is especially critical in window of opportunity trials, where no therapeutic effect is expected, or in studies of agentswhose biological effect is weaker or less well-defined than the AIs studied in POETIC., In such cases harmonizing baseline and end-of-treatment sampling procedures (ie,  paired biop-sies, as used in FAIMOS),  as well as inclusion of a controlgroup,  is likely advisable, and is typically lacking when as-sessment of routinely available archival tissue samples is performed., Retrospective analyses of paired tissue specimens com- monly performed in situations where mature outcome clinicaldata are required, are even more likely to suffer from technical differences in tissue sampling., Examples include the compari- son of residual disease (at surgery) with pretreatment biopsiesin the neoadjuvant setting to identify correlates of drug resis-tance, or metastatic disease (biopsies) to resected primaries (atsurgery) to identify features associated with disease progression and dissemination., Attempts to control for potential confound- ing factors arising from technical issues in retrospective studiesrequire both the recognition that this phenomenon is presentand a database of important artifactual changes, as Gao et al.provided in their supplemental data for presurgical ER breast cancer., While some of these are likely to be common to other histologies attention to other settings is necessary to accountfor disease-specific alterations., Failure to consider and controlfor such changes can and undoubtedly will, result in spuriousresults and misleading conclusions., For those working in this area, take heed: the sample matters. qa_pairs.question: What is the main objective of the research in this paper?
qa_pairs.answer: The main objective of the research in this paper is to highlight the significant impact of sampling methodology on gene expression analyses in breast cancer. The authors emphasize the importance of considering pre-analytical variables, such as tissue processing delays and sampling techniques, which can lead to artifactual changes in gene expression data. They aim to inform the design and interpretation of gene expression biomarker studies, particularly in the context of clinical trials, by illustrating how these confounding factors can mask real treatment-induced changes and potentially lead to misleading conclusions.

qa_pairs.question: Can you summarize the abstract of the paper?
qa_pairs.answer: The abstract of the paper discusses the significant impact of gene expression analyses in breast cancer research, particularly following the advancements in microarray technologies and RNA-seq. It highlights how these analyses have led to the development of molecular classification schemes and prognostic gene expression classifiers that refine treatment decisions for breast cancer patients. The editorial emphasizes the importance of accurate sample collection and handling, as illustrated by a study that revealed artifactual gene expression changes due to differences in processing between core biopsies and surgical specimens. The authors stress the need for careful design in gene expression biomarker studies to avoid confounding factors that could lead to misleading conclusions, ultimately underscoring that the integrity of the sample is crucial for reliable results in breast cancer research.

qa_pairs.question: What are the softwares and computational tools that were used in this paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The paper discusses various software and computational tools used in gene expression analyses related to breast cancer. Here are the key tools mentioned:

1. **Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC)** - A large-scale initiative for drug screening in cancer cell lines.
2. **Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia** - A resource that provides data on cancer cell lines and their drug sensitivity profiles.
3. **Connectivity Map project** - Investigates the effects of drug treatments on the transcriptomic state of cancer cells.
4. **PharmacoDB** - An integrative database for mining in vitro anticancer drug screening studies.
5. **PharmacoGx** - An R package designed for the analysis of large pharmacogenomic datasets.

These tools facilitate the analysis of gene expression data and the understanding of drug responses in cancer research.

qa_pairs.question: Describe the methodology used in the paper.
qa_pairs.answer:
The methodology used in the paper involves a comparative analysis of gene expression data from breast cancer samples obtained through different sampling methods. Specifically, the authors analyze whole-genome expression data from estrogen receptor (ER) positive breast cancer samples collected via core needle biopsy at baseline and paired surgical specimens obtained after two weeks of preoperative aromatase inhibitor (AI) treatment, as part of the POETIC trial.

Key aspects of the methodology include:

1. **Sample Collection**: The study compares samples collected through two different methods: core needle biopsies processed directly and surgical specimens that underwent routine handling, often with delays for clinical assessment. This difference in processing times is critical as it affects the ischemic time and, consequently, the integrity of the samples.

2. **Gene Expression Analysis**: The authors focus on identifying alterations in gene expression due to treatment with aromatase inhibitors and also examine changes in the control group. They highlight that substantial gene expression changes can occur due to pre-analytical variables in sample collection and handling.

3. **Comparison of Treatment and Control Groups**: The study utilizes data from both treated and control groups to discern whether observed gene expression changes are due to the treatment or are artifacts of the sampling methodology. This is further supported by an analysis of another trial (FAIMoS) where post-AI samples were collected through repeat core biopsies prior to surgical resection.

4. **Addressing Confounding Factors**: The authors discuss the potential confounding factors arising from the differences in sampling techniques and emphasize the importance of harmonizing sampling procedures in clinical studies to avoid misleading conclusions.

5. **Data Interpretation**: The findings are interpreted in the context of how sampling methodology can lead to the detection of artifactual gene expression changes, which may mask genuine treatment-induced changes.

Overall, the methodology underscores the significance of sample handling and processing in gene expression studies, particularly in the context of breast cancer research, and advocates for careful design in biomarker studies to ensure accurate interpretation of results.

qa_pairs.question: What are the key findings of the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The key findings of the paper "Gene Expression Analyses in Breast Cancer Sample Matters" by Benjamin Haibe-Kains and David W. Cescon can be summarized as follows:

1. **Impact of Gene Expression Profiling**: The paper emphasizes the significant role of gene expression profiling in breast cancer research, particularly in the classification of molecular subtypes and in guiding treatment decisions alongside traditional pathological measurements.

2. **Prognostic Gene Expression Classifiers**: The development and validation of various prognostic gene expression classifiers (e.g., OncotypeDX, Prosigna, Mammaprint) have improved decision-making regarding adjuvant chemotherapy, allowing for more tailored treatment approaches and reducing unnecessary exposure to toxic therapies for many patients.

3. **Artifact in Gene Expression Changes**: A critical finding from the referenced study by Gao et al. is that gene expression changes observed in breast cancer samples can be significantly influenced by pre-analytical variables, such as delays in tissue processing. This can lead to misleading interpretations of treatment effects.

4. **Comparison of Sample Handling**: The authors highlight that differences in sample handling (e.g., core needle biopsies processed directly versus surgical specimens processed after delays) can produce substantial differences in gene expression profiles, potentially confounding results related to treatment effects.

5. **Need for Controlled Sampling**: The editorial stresses the importance of harmonizing sampling procedures and including control groups in clinical studies to mitigate the risk of confounding factors affecting gene expression analyses. This is particularly crucial in window-of-opportunity trials where no therapeutic effect is expected.

6. **Caution in Retrospective Studies**: The authors caution that retrospective analyses of paired tissue specimens are likely to suffer from technical differences in sampling, which can lead to spurious results if not properly accounted for.

7. **Conclusion**: The overarching message is that careful consideration of sample collection and handling is essential in gene expression studies to avoid misleading conclusions and to ensure the reliability of findings in breast cancer research.

Overall, the paper underscores the necessity of rigorous methodological standards in gene expression analyses to enhance the validity of research outcomes in breast cancer.

qa_pairs.question: How was the data analyzed in the study?
qa_pairs.answer: The data in the study was analyzed through a comparison of whole-genome expression data from estrogen receptor (ER) breast cancer samples obtained via core needle biopsy at baseline and paired surgical specimens collected after two weeks of preoperative aromatase inhibitor (AI) treatment or control from the POETIC trial. The analysis focused on identifying gene expression alterations in the treated group, highlighting major signaling pathways affected by estrogen deprivation. Additionally, the study addressed the impact of pre-analytical variables in sample collection and handling, noting that differences in processing times between core biopsies and surgical specimens could lead to significant variations in gene expression. The authors concluded that the sampling differences in serial specimen collection resulted in the detection of artifactual changes in some genes, while also masking real treatment-induced changes in others. This analysis was further supported by examining data from a different trial (FAIMoS) to control for confounding factors related to the sampling methodology.

qa_pairs.question: Was the data in the study pre-processed in anyway? If so how?
qa_pairs.answer:
Yes, the data in the study was pre-processed in several ways. The editorial discusses the handling of breast cancer samples, specifically highlighting the differences in processing between core needle biopsies and surgical specimens. 

1. **Direct Processing vs. Routine Handling**: The baseline core biopsies were processed directly after collection, while the surgical specimens underwent routine handling following resection, which often included delays for clinical assessment. This difference in processing methods could lead to variations in gene expression due to factors like ischemic time, which can affect cellular responses and sample integrity.

2. **Impact of Pre-analytical Variables**: The study emphasizes that substantial changes in gene expression can be attributed to pre-analytical variables in sample collection and handling. For example, the core biopsies and surgical specimens were subjected to different ischemic times, which could produce cellular responses that affect the integrity of the samples.

3. **Comparison of Samples**: The authors analyzed and compared whole-genome expression data from the core needle biopsies and paired surgical specimens obtained after treatment. This comparison aimed to identify gene expression alterations and assess the impact of treatment versus the effects of sample handling.

Overall, the editorial underscores the importance of considering these pre-processing factors when interpreting gene expression data in breast cancer research, as they can lead to artifactual changes that may confound the results.

qa_pairs.question: What conclusions were drawn in the paper?
qa_pairs.answer: The conclusions drawn in the paper highlight the significant impact of sampling methodology on gene expression analyses in breast cancer. The authors emphasize that differences in how tissue samples are collected and processed can lead to artifactual changes in gene expression data, which may obscure true treatment effects. Specifically, they note that the study by Gao et al. demonstrated that gene expression changes attributed to aromatase inhibitor treatment were, in fact, influenced by pre-analytical variables such as ischemic time and sample handling differences between core biopsies and surgical specimens. The authors advocate for careful consideration of these technical confounders in the design and interpretation of gene expression biomarker studies, particularly in clinical settings where such controls are often lacking. They stress that harmonizing sampling procedures and including control groups are crucial for obtaining reliable results, warning that failure to account for these factors can lead to misleading conclusions. Ultimately, the authors assert that "the sample matters" in the context of gene expression analyses in breast cancer research.

qa_pairs.question: Can you provide a summary of the literature review from the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The literature review in the paper by Haibe-Kains and Cescon discusses the significant advancements in gene expression analyses in breast cancer, particularly since the introduction of microarray technologies. It highlights the vast amount of data generated from both archived clinical materials and prospective studies, which has been made accessible through public repositories. This accessibility has allowed researchers to conduct discovery and validation studies to better understand the molecular mechanisms underlying tumor behavior and treatment responses.

The review emphasizes the critical role of gene expression profiling in breast cancer research and clinical practice, noting its influence on molecular classification schemes, such as intrinsic subtypes. It underscores the importance of gene expression analysis, which complements traditional pathological assessments of hormone receptors (ER, PR, HER2) in guiding treatment decisions for patients.

The authors discuss the development of prognostic gene expression classifiers, such as OncotypeDX and Mammaprint, which have refined the decision-making process regarding adjuvant chemotherapy, ultimately benefiting many patients by avoiding unnecessary treatments.

Furthermore, the review addresses the findings of Gao et al. regarding the impact of sampling methodologies on gene expression results in breast cancer. It highlights how pre-analytical variables, such as delays in tissue processing, can lead to significant alterations in gene expression profiles, potentially confounding the interpretation of treatment effects. The authors stress the need for careful consideration of these factors in the design and analysis of gene expression biomarker studies, particularly in clinical settings where controlling for such variables is challenging.

Overall, the literature review provides a comprehensive overview of the advancements in gene expression analysis in breast cancer, the implications for clinical practice, and the importance of methodological rigor in research to avoid misleading conclusions.

qa_pairs.question: What future research directions do the authors suggest in the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The authors suggest several future research directions in the paper. They emphasize the importance of addressing technical confounders in gene expression analyses, particularly in clinical settings where controlled experimental designs are challenging to implement. Future studies should focus on:

1. **Harmonizing Sampling Procedures**: There is a need for standardizing baseline and end-of-treatment sampling procedures, such as using paired biopsies and including control groups in clinical trials. This is particularly crucial in window of opportunity trials where no therapeutic effect is expected.

2. **Prospective Studies**: The authors advocate for more prospective studies that evaluate the pharmacodynamic effects of novel therapies, ensuring that these studies include control arms to better assess drug effects and potential predictive biomarkers.

3. **Addressing Technical Differences in Retrospective Analyses**: They highlight the necessity of recognizing and controlling for potential confounding factors in retrospective studies, especially when comparing residual disease with pretreatment biopsies or metastatic disease with resected primaries.

4. **Database of Artifactual Changes**: The authors suggest the creation of a comprehensive database that catalogs important artifactual changes in gene expression due to technical issues, which would aid researchers in identifying and controlling for these changes in their analyses.

5. **Exploration of Disease-Specific Alterations**: They call for attention to disease-specific alterations in gene expression, indicating that while some technical issues may be common across different cancer types, others may be unique and require tailored approaches.

Overall, the authors stress that careful consideration of sample handling and analysis methodologies is essential to avoid misleading conclusions in breast cancer research.

qa_pairs.question: What statistical techniques were used in the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The paper discusses various aspects of gene expression analyses in breast cancer but does not explicitly detail the statistical techniques used in the studies it references. However, it does mention the analysis of whole-genome expression data and the comparison of gene expression alterations between different sample types (core needle biopsies and surgical specimens). 

In general, studies of this nature often employ statistical techniques such as:

1. **Differential Expression Analysis**: This is commonly used to identify genes that show statistically significant differences in expression levels between different conditions or groups (e.g., treated vs. control).

2. **Multivariate Analysis**: Techniques like principal component analysis (PCA) or clustering methods may be used to identify patterns in gene expression data.

3. **Regression Analysis**: This can be used to model the relationship between gene expression levels and clinical outcomes or treatment responses.

4. **Survival Analysis**: Often employed to assess the prognostic value of gene expression profiles in relation to patient survival.

5. **Correction for Multiple Testing**: Given the high dimensionality of gene expression data, techniques such as the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure may be used to control the false discovery rate.

While the editorial emphasizes the importance of sample collection and handling, it does not provide specific details on the statistical methods employed in the referenced studies. For precise statistical techniques, one would need to refer to the original studies cited within the editorial.

qa_pairs.question: Can you describe the experimental setup in the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The experimental setup described in the paper involves the analysis of gene expression in breast cancer samples collected through a specific clinical trial, the POETIC trial. Here are the key components of the experimental setup:

1. **Sample Collection**: The study analyzed estrogen receptor (ER) positive breast cancer samples obtained through two different methods:
   - Core needle biopsies taken at baseline.
   - Paired surgical specimens collected after two weeks of preoperative aromatase inhibitor (AI) treatment or control.

2. **Comparison of Samples**: The researchers compared whole-genome expression data from the baseline core biopsies and the surgical specimens. This comparison aimed to identify gene expression alterations due to the treatment and to assess the impact of sample handling on gene expression results.

3. **Pre-analytical Variables**: The study highlighted the importance of pre-analytical variables, noting that the core biopsies were processed directly, while the surgical specimens underwent routine handling that often included delays for clinical assessment. This difference in processing could lead to variations in ischemic time, potentially affecting cellular responses and sample integrity.

4. **Control Group Analysis**: The authors also referenced an analysis from a different trial (FAIMoS) to address potential confounding factors. In this trial, post-AI samples were collected through a repeat core biopsy prior to surgical resection, allowing for a clearer comparison of gene expression changes attributable to treatment versus those caused by sampling methodology.

5. **Findings**: The analysis revealed that many genes with altered expression between baseline and surgery in the AI-treated group were also affected in the control group, indicating that some observed changes were likely due to sampling differences rather than treatment effects.

Overall, the experimental setup emphasizes the critical role of sample handling and processing in gene expression studies, particularly in clinical settings where such variables can introduce confounding factors.

qa_pairs.question: What are the implications of the research findings?
qa_pairs.answer:
The implications of the research findings presented in the editorial by Haibe-Kains and Cescon are significant for both the field of breast cancer research and clinical practice. Here are the key implications:

1. **Importance of Sample Handling**: The findings underscore the critical role that sample collection and handling play in gene expression analyses. The research highlights that differences in ischemic time and processing methods can lead to substantial alterations in gene expression profiles, which may confound the interpretation of results. This suggests that meticulous attention to sample handling protocols is essential to ensure the integrity of molecular data.

2. **Impact on Treatment Decisions**: The editorial emphasizes that gene expression profiling is integral to the molecular classification of breast cancer and informs treatment decisions. Misinterpretation of gene expression changes due to technical artifacts could lead to inappropriate treatment plans, potentially exposing patients to unnecessary therapies or depriving them of effective treatments.

3. **Need for Standardization**: The authors advocate for the standardization of sampling procedures in clinical trials, particularly in window-of-opportunity studies where no therapeutic effect is expected. This standardization is crucial for accurately assessing drug effects and identifying predictive biomarkers, thereby enhancing the reliability of clinical trial outcomes.

4. **Awareness of Confounding Factors**: The editorial calls for increased awareness among researchers and clinicians regarding the potential confounding factors that can arise from technical differences in sample collection. Recognizing these factors is vital for drawing valid conclusions from both prospective and retrospective studies.

5. **Guidance for Future Research**: The findings serve as a cautionary note for future research in breast cancer and other malignancies. Researchers are encouraged to implement rigorous controls and harmonize sampling methods to minimize the risk of spurious results. This approach will improve the robustness of findings and contribute to more reliable biomarker development.

6. **Broader Applicability**: While the focus is on breast cancer, the implications of the findings may extend to other cancer types and research areas. The need for careful consideration of sample integrity and handling is a common challenge in cancer research, suggesting that the lessons learned from this study could benefit the broader oncology community.

In summary, the editorial highlights the critical importance of sample integrity in gene expression analyses, the potential consequences for treatment decisions, and the need for standardized protocols to enhance the reliability of research findings in breast cancer and beyond.

qa_pairs.question: What are the limitations and delimitations mentioned in the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The paper discusses several limitations and delimitations related to gene expression analyses in breast cancer. Here are the key points:

### Limitations:
1. **Technical Confounders**: The paper highlights that technical confounders can significantly affect gene expression results, particularly in clinical settings where controlled experimental designs are challenging to implement. This includes variations in sample collection and handling that can lead to artifactual changes in gene expression.

2. **Retrospective Analyses**: Retrospective studies often suffer from technical differences in tissue sampling, which can lead to spurious results and misleading conclusions. The authors emphasize the need for careful consideration of these technical issues when interpreting results from such studies.

qa_pairs.question: Can you explain the technical terms used in the paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
Certainly! Here are explanations of some of the technical terms used in the paper:

1. **Gene Expression Analyses**: This refers to the methods used to measure the activity (expression) of genes in a sample, which can indicate how genes are functioning in different conditions, such as in cancer.

2. **Microarray Technologies**: A high-throughput technology that allows researchers to measure the expression levels of thousands of genes simultaneously. It involves hybridizing cDNA or RNA samples to a chip containing probes for specific genes.

3. **RNA-seq (RNA sequencing)**: A next-generation sequencing technique that provides a comprehensive view of the transcriptome, allowing for the quantification of gene expression levels and the discovery of novel transcripts.

4. **Intrinsic Subtypes**: These are classifications of breast cancer based on gene expression profiles. They help in understanding the biological behavior of the cancer and in tailoring treatment strategies.

5. **Estrogen Receptor (ER)**: A protein that, when bound by estrogen, can promote the growth of certain types of breast cancer. Its presence is a key factor in determining treatment options.

6. **Progesterone Receptor (PR)**: Similar to ER, this receptor is involved in the growth of breast tissue and can influence the behavior of breast cancer.

7. **Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2 (HER2)**: A protein that can promote the growth of cancer cells. In some breast cancers, high levels of HER2 are associated with aggressive disease and specific treatment options.

8. **Prognostic Gene Expression Classifiers**: These are tests that analyze the expression of specific genes to predict the likely course of the disease and the effectiveness of treatments, helping to guide clinical decisions.

9. **Adjuvant Chemotherapy**: A treatment given in addition to the primary treatment (usually surgery) to maximize its effectiveness, often used to eliminate any remaining cancer cells.

10. **Pre-analytical Variables**: Factors that can affect the quality and integrity of biological samples before analysis, such as the time between sample collection and processing.

11. **Ischemic Time**: The duration that tissue is deprived of adequate blood supply, which can lead to cellular changes that affect gene expression.

12. **Wound Healing Response**: The biological process that occurs after tissue injury, which can alter gene expression and potentially confound experimental results.

13. **Pharmacogenomic Studies**: Research that examines how genes affect a person's response to drugs, aiming to develop effective, safe medications tailored to individual genetic profiles.

14. **Window of Opportunity Trials**: Clinical trials designed to evaluate the effects of a treatment during a specific time frame before the main treatment, often used to assess early biological responses.

15. **Retrospective Analyses**: Studies that look back at existing data or samples to find correlations or outcomes, often used when prospective data collection is not feasible.

These terms are central to understanding the methodologies and implications of the research discussed in the paper, particularly in the context of breast cancer treatment and gene expression profiling.

qa_pairs.question: Can you summarize the research paper?
qa_pairs.answer:
The editorial titled "Gene Expression Analyses in Breast Cancer Sample Matters" by Benjamin Haibe-Kains and David W. A key focus of the editorial is a study by Gao et al., which reveals that gene expression changes observed in breast cancer samples can be significantly influenced by pre-analytical variables, such as delays in tissue processing. The authors discuss how these variables can lead to artifactual gene expression changes, potentially confounding the interpretation of treatment effects in clinical trials. They stress the importance of harmonizing sample collection and handling procedures to minimize such confounding factors, particularly in clinical settings where controlled experimental designs are challenging.

The editorial concludes with a cautionary note about the necessity of considering sample integrity and processing conditions when interpreting gene expression data in breast cancer research, underscoring that the way samples are collected and processed can profoundly affect the results and conclusions drawn from studies.
